document.docAuthor: Nattier, Romain, Jourdan, Hervé, Mille, Christian & Chazeau, Jean
document.masterDocTitle: An annotated checklist of the Coccinellidae (Coleoptera) from New Caledonia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: An annotated checklist of the Coccinellidae (Coleoptera) from New Caledonia

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Coccinella repanda
Thunberg, 1781
: 18
—synonymized by
Mulsant 1850
: 1022
(as
Coccinella repanda Casström
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
The synonymy, established by
Mulsant ( 1850 )
(first reviewer who attributed the species authorship to Casström) is currently accepted by recent authors (e.g.
Pope 1987
;
Slipinski 2007
).
C. transversalis
is a very widespread species, it has been recorded widely in the Asia-Pacific region, from India to Polynesia, including Australia , Tasmania, Papua New Guinea , New Zealand , Vanuatu , Solomon Islands , Fiji Islands , Micronesia , Cook Islands , Wallis & Futuna , and French Polynesia . In New Caledonia , it is a common species on both coasts, including high altitudes (greater than 1,000m ), Isle of Pines, Belep Islands, Loyalty Islands, Surprise, Chesterfield and Walpole islands. This is a polyphagous predator of various Hemiptera ( Aphididae , Psyllidae, Coccomorpha ). Humans have promoted its spread and we consider it as introduced according to its biological traits (since aphids are all introduced in New Caledonia ; CM & HJ, unpublished data) and distribution. When prey is scarce, it is also known to feed on pollen and extrafloral nectaries (
Evans 2000
) which are uncommon in the New Caledonian native flora. This species has attracted great interest in biocontrol especially against aphids (
Aphis gossypii Glover
) and against the pseudococcid
Planococcus citri (Risso) (
Waterhouse 1998
)
.
